reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus low-friction moral trade can make a mostly-great future plausible, and that this supports shifting attention from mere survival to flourishing failure-modes. If that pillar collapses, a substantial portion of the essay’s positive update and practical emphasis weakens, though the essay has other strands (e.g., arguments against WAM-convergence; threats; blockers; metaethical uncertainty), so it wouldn’t fully collapse. The objection’s strength is moderate: it effectively highlights that the essay relies heavily on illustrative analogies and qualitative claims about ‘enormous gains from trade’ without specifying a toy model or decision-theoretic assumptions that would let one predict sign/magnitude of post-bargaining value, so it undercuts confidence in the quantified 5–10% update and in the robustness of the trade-based optimism. However, it doesn’t directly show that trade is unlikely or net harmful; it’s mainly an underdetermination/robustness critique, and the essay itself partially anticipates uncertainty and failure modes (threats, resource-compatibility limits), which reduces marginal force. Most claims in the critique are plausible and consistent with the essay (lack of formalization, sensitivity to bargaining details), though the ‘numerology’/‘vibe’ framing is somewhat rhetorical/overstated. The critique is clear, focused on one main methodological vulnerability, and contains little dead weight.
title: Moral trade argument lacks causal model to generate falsifiable predictions
